chapter_1_The_Basics

Class StaticMethodsInInterfaces

  • java.lang.Object
    • chapter_1_The_Basics.Recipe_1_6_Static_Methods_in_Interfaces

  • public class StaticMethodsInInterfaces
extends java.lang.Object

    (1.6.) Static Methods in Interfaces


    1. TO DO

      - add a class-level utility method to an interface, along with an implementation

    2. HOW

      - add the static keyword on the interface method and add the implementation for it

    3. EQ.

      • sortingStringsNaturalOrder(List) - sorting Strings by natural order (lexicographically)
      • sortingStringsReverseOrder(List) - sorting Strings by reverse order
      • sortingStringsByLowerCase(List) - sorting Strings by lower case
      • sortingStringsByNameLength(List) - sorting Strings by name length
      • sortingStringsByNameLengthThenLexicographically(List) - sorting Strings by name length and then lexicographically

    ❗ The implementation of the class-level method cannot be overridden.
    Access the method using the interface name. Classes do not need to implement an interface to use its static methods.
    Static methods in interfaces remove the need to create separate utility classes, but the option is still available if a design calls for it.

    ❗ Important:
    • Static methods must have an implementation
    • You cannot override a static method
    • Call static methods from an interface name
    • You do not need to implement an interface to use the static methods

      • sortingStringsByNameLengthThenLexicographically

        protected static void sortingStringsByNameLengthThenLexicographically(java.util.List<java.lang.String> bonds)
        ◊◊◊ Sorting Strings by Name Length Then Lexicographically ◊◊◊ 
             List<String> sorted = bonds.stream()
            .sorted(Comparator.comparing(String::length)
                    .thenComparing(Comparator.naturalOrder()))
            .collect(Collectors.toList());
        Parameters:
        bonds - list of Bond actors
